introduction.text: This document gives a high-level description of the tables that make up the EnsEMBL core schema. Tables are grouped into logical groups, and the purpose of each table is explained. It is intended to allow people to familiarise themselves with the schema when encountering it for the first time, or when they need to use some tables that they've not used before. Note that while some of the more important columns in some of the tables are discussed, this document makes no attempt to enumerate all of the names, types and contents of every single table. Some concepts which are referred to in the table descriptions are given at the end of this document; these are linked to from the table description where appropriate.

process.intro: Different tables are populated throughout the gene build process:
process.step: Create empty schema, populate meta table
Load DNA - populates dna, clone, contig, chromosome, assembly tables
Analyze DNA (raw computes) - populates genomic feature/analysis tables
Build genes - populates exon, transcript,etc. gene-related tables
Analyze genes - populate protein_feature, xref tables, interpro

table.name: dna
table.description: Contains DNA sequence. This table has a 1:1 relationship with the contig table.

tableref.reason: Allows xrefs to have more than one name

table.name: assembly
table.description: Describes how contig sequences make up the chromosomal sequence. The data in this table defines the "static golden path", i.e. the best effort draft full genome sequence as determined by the UCSC or NCBI (depending which assembly you are using) Each row represents a contig (raw_id, FK from contig table) at least part of which is present in the golden path. The part of the contig that is in the path is delimited by fields raw_start and raw_end and the absolute position within the golden path chromosome (chromosome_id) is given by chr_start and chr_end. Each contig is in a "supercontig" such as a "fingerprint clone contig" or NT contig and the super contig is identified by the superctg_name column and the position of the specified section of the contig within its supercontig is given by fields superctg_start and superctg_end.

conceptref.name: co-ordinates
conceptref.reason: Chromosome start and end positions are stored in chromosomal co-ordinates whereas the contig start and end positions are stored in contig co-ordinates.

conceptref.name: supercontigs
conceptref.reason: The mapping between contigs and supercontigs is also stored in the assembly table.

table.name: assembly_exception
table.description: TBC

table.name: karyotype
table.description: Describes bands that can be stained on the chromosome.

table.name: exon
table.description: Stores data about exons. Associated with transcripts via exon_transcript. Allows access to contigs via the contig_* columns. The sticky_rank differentiates between fragments of the same exon; i.e for exons that span multiple contigs, all the fragments are in this table with the same id, but different sticky_rank values.

tableref.name: exon_transcript
tableref.reason: Used to associate exons with transcripts.

conceptref.name: sticky_rank
conceptref.reason: Differentiates between exons that span multiple contigs.

table.name: exon_stable_id
table.description: Relates exon IDs in this release to release-independent stable identifiers.

conceptref.name: stable_id
conceptref.reason: Describes the rationale behind the use of stable identifiers.

table.name: transcript
table.description: TBC Note that a transcript is usually associated with a translation, but may not be, e.g. in the case of pseudogenes and RNA genes (those that code for RNA molecules).

table.name: transcript_stable_id
table.description: Relates transcript IDs in this release to release-independent stable identifiers.

conceptref.name: stable_id
conceptref.reason: Describes the rationale behind the use of stable identifiers.

table.name: exon_transcript
table.description: Relationship table linking exons with transcripts. The rank column ndicates the 5' to 3' position of the exon within the transcript, i.e. a rank of 1 means the exon is the 5' most within this transcript.

tableref.name: exon
tableref.reason: One of the entities related by the exon_transcript table.

tableref.name: transcript
tableref.reason: One of the entities related by the exon_transcript table.

table.name: gene
table.description: Allows transcripts to be related to genes.

table.name: gene_stable_id
table.description: Relates gene IDs in this release to release-independent stable identifiers.

conceptref.name: stable_id
conceptref.reason: Describes the rationale behind the use of stable identifiers.

table.name: gene_description
table.description: Where appropriate, allows specific genes to be given a description.

tableref.name: gene
tableref.reason: for the actual gene.

table.name: translation
table.description: Describes which parts of which exons are used in translation. The seq_start and seq_end columns are 1-based offsets into the *relative* coordinate system of start_exon_id and end_exon_id. i.e, if the translation starts at the first base of the exon, seq_start would be 1.

table.name: translation_stable_id
table.description: Relates translation IDs in this release to release-independent stable identifiers.

conceptref.name: stable_id
conceptref.reason: Describes the rationale behind the use of stable identifiers.

table.name: supporting_feature
table.description: Describes the exon prediction process by linking exons to DNA or protein alignment features. As in several other tables, the feature_id column is a foreign key; the feature_type column specifies which table feature_id refers to.

table.name: meta
table.description: Stores data about the data in the current schema. Taxonomy information, version information and the default value for the type column in the assembly table are stored here. Unlike other tables, data in the meta table is stored as key/value pairs.

tableref.name: assembly
tableref.reason: The default value for assembly.type is stored in the meta table.

table.name: meta_coord
table.description: TBC

table.name: analysis
table.description: Usually describes a program and some database that together are used to create a feature on a piece of sequence. Each feature is marked with an analysis_id. The most important column is logic_name, which is used by the webteam to render a feature correctly on contigview (or even retrieve the right feature). Logic_name is also used in the pipeline to identify the analysis which has to run in a given status of the pipeline. The module column tells the pipeline which Perl module does the whole analysis, typically a RunnableDB module.

table.name: dna_align_feature
table.description: Stores DNA sequence alignments generated from Blast (or Blast-like) comparisons.

table.name: protein_align_feature
table.description: Stores translation alignments generated from Blast (or Blast-like) comparisons.

table.name: repeat_feature
table.description: Describes sequence repeat regions.

table.name: marker_feature
table.description: Used to describe marker positions.

tableref.name: marker
tableref.reason: Stores details about the markers themselves.

tableref.name: marker_synonym
tableref.reason: Holds alternative names for markers.

table.name: qtl_feature
table.description: Describes Quantitative Trail Loci (QTL) positions as obtained from inbreeding experiments. Note the values in this table are in chromosomal co-ordinates. Also, this table is not populated all schemas.

tableref.name: qtl
tableref.reason: Describes the markers used to define a QTL.

tableref.name: qtl_synonym
tableref.reason: Stores alternative names for QTLs

table.name: prediction_transcript
table.description: Stores information about ab initio gene transcript predictions.

table.name: simple_feature
table.description: Describes general genomic features that don't fit into any of the more specific feature tables.

table.name: protein_feature
table.description: Describes features on the translations (as opposed to the DNA sequence itself), i.e. parts of the peptide. In peptide co-ordinates rather than contig co-ordinates.

tableref.name: analysis
tableref.reason: Describes how protein features were derived.

table.name: qtl
table.description: Describes the markers (of which there may be up to three) which define Quantitative Trait Loci. Note that QTL is a statistical technique used to find links between certain expressed traits and regions in a genetic map.

tableref.name: qtl_synonym
tableref.reason: Describes alternative names for QTLs

table.name: qtl_synonym
table.description: Describes alternative names for Quantitative Trait Loci (QTLs).

table.name: marker
table.description: Stores data about the marker itself - e.g. the primer sequences used.

tableref.name: marker_synonym
tableref.reason: Stores alternative names for markers.

table.name: marker_map_location
table.description: Allows storage of information about the postion of a marker - these are positions on genetic or radiation hybrid maps (as opposed to positions on the assembly, which EnsEMBL has determined and which are stored in marker_feature).

tableref.name: marker
tableref.reason: Stores marker data.

tableref.name: marker_feature
tableref.reason: Stores marker positions on the assembly.

table.name: marker_synonym
table.description: Stores alternative names for markers, as well as their sources.

tableref.name: marker
tableref.reason: Stores the original marker.

table.name: map
table.description: Stores the names of different genetic or radiation hybrid maps, for which there is marker map information.

tableref.name: marker
tableref.reason: Stores the original marker.

table.name: repeat_consensus
table.description: Stores consenus sequences obtained from analysing repeat features.

tablegroup.name: ID Mapping
tablegroup.description: Tables involved in mapping identifiers between releases

table.name: mapping_session
table.description: Stores details of ID mapping sessions - a mapping session represents the session when stable IDs where mapped from one database to another. Details of the "old" and "new" databases are stored.

tableref.name: stable_id_event
tableref.reason: Stores details of what happened during the mapping session.

conceptref.name: stable_id
conceptref.reason: Describes the need for ID mapping.

table.name: stable_id_event
table.description: Represents what happened to all gene, transcript and translation stable IDs during a mapping session. This includes which IDs where deleted, created and related to each other. Each event is represented by one or more rows in the table.

tableref.name: mapping_session
tableref.reason: Describes the session when events stored in this table occured.

table.name: gene_archive
table.description: Contains a snapshot of the stable IDs associated with genes deleted or changed between releases. Includes gene, transcript and translation stable IDs.

table.name: peptide_archive
table.description: Contains the peptides for deleted or changed translations.

tablegroup.name: Exernal references
tablegroup.description: Tables used for storing links to and details about objects that are stored in other databases

table.name: xref
table.description: Holds data about objects which are external to EnsEMBL, but need to be associated with EnsEMBL objects. Information about the database that the external object is stored in is held in the external_db table entry referred to by the external_db column.

tableref.name: external_db
tableref.reason: Describes the database that xrefs are stored in

tableref.name: external_synonym
tableref.reason: Allows xrefs to have more than one name

table.name: external_db
table.description: Stores data about the external databases in which the objects described in the xref table are stored.

tableref.name: xref
tableref.reason: Holds data about the external objects that are stored in the external_dbs.

table.name: external_synonym
table.description: Some xref objects can be referred to by more than one name. This table relates names to xref IDs.

tableref.name: xref
tableref.reason: Holds most of the data about xrefs.

table.name: object_xref
table.description: Describes links between EnsEMBL objects and objects held in external databases. The EnsEMBL object can be one of several types; the type is held in the ensembl_object_type column. The ID of the particular EnsEMBL gene, translation or whatever is given in the ensembl_id column. The xref_id points to the entry in the xref table that holds data about the external object.Each EnsEMBL object can be associated with zero or more xrefs. An xref object can be associated with one or more EnsEMBL objects.

tableref.name: xref
tableref.reason: Stores the data about each externally-referenced object.

tableref.name: go_xref
tableref.reason: Stores extra data for relationships to GO objects.

tableref.name: identity_xref
tableref.reason: Stores data about how 'good' the relationships are

table.name: go_xref
table.description: Links between EnsEMBL objects and external objects produced by GO (Gene Ontology) require some additional data which is not stored in the object_xref table.

tableref.name: object_xref
tableref.reason: Stores basic, non GO-specific information for GO xrefs

table.name: identity_xref
table.description: Describes how well a particular xref obeject matches the EnsEMBL object.

tableref.name: object_xref
tableref.reason: Stores basic information about EnsEMBL object-xref mapping

tablegroup.name: Miscellaneous
tablegroup.description: Tables that don't fit anywhere else.

table.name: interpro
table.description: Allows storage of links to the InterPro database. InterPro is a database of protein families, domains and functional sites in which identifiable features found in known proteins can be applied to unknown protein sequences.

concept.name: co-ordinates
concept.description: There are several different co-ordinate systems used in the EnsEMBL database and API. For every co-ordinate system, the fundamental unit is one base. The differences between co-ordinate systems lie in where a particular numbered base lies, and the start position it is relative to. CONTIG co-ordinates, also called 'raw contig' co-ordinates or 'clone fragments' are relative to the first base of the first contig of a clone. Note that the numbering is from 1, i.e. the very first base of the first contig of a clone is numbered 1, not 0. In CHROMOSOMAL co-ordinates, the co-ordinates are relative to the first base of the chromosome. Again, numbering is from 1.

concept.name: supercontigs
concept.description: A supercontig is made up of a group of adjacent or overlapping contigs.

concept.name: sticky_rank
concept.description: The sticky_rank differentiates between fragments of the same exon; i.e for exons that span multiple contigs, all the fragments would have the same ID, but different sticky_rank values

concept.name: stable_id
concept.description: Gene predictions have changed over the various releases of the EnsEMBL databases. To allow the user to track particular gene predictions over changing co-ordinates, each gene-related prediction is given a 'stable identifier'. If a prediction looks similar between two releases, we try to give it the same name, even though it may have changed position and/or had some sequence changes.

concept.name: cigar_line
concept.description: This allows the compact storage of gapped alignments by storing the maximum extent of the matches and then a text string which encodes the placement of gaps inside the alignment. Colloquially inside Ensembl this is called a and its adoption has shrunk the number of rows in the feature table around 4-fold.
